item.title: Kizza Besigye, Main Opposition Candidate in Uganda, Is Arrested Again
item.description: Mr. Besigye was arrested for the second time in two days as voting continued amid unrest in the capital.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Opinion: World War I’s Iconic, Ironic Battle
item.description: It’s the centennial of Verdun. But what exactly are we commemorating?
item.dc:creator: PAUL JANKOWSKI
item.media:description: French troops under shellfire during the Battle of Verdun.

item.title: Kosovo Opposition Releases Tear Gas in Parliament
item.description: Lawmakers released multiple canisters of the gas, adding to a series of protests over corruption, unemployment and deals struck with Serbia and Montenegro.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Security officers wore gas masks while inspecting the Parliament building in Pristina, Kosovo, on Friday after opposition lawmakers disrupted the first session of the year by releasing tear gas.

item.title: U.S. Airstrikes on ISIS Camp in Libya Kill More Than 40
item.description: The airstrikes targeted a senior Tunisian operative linked to two major terrorist attacks in Tunisia last year, a Western official said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT, DECLAN WALSH and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Behind Chinese Leader’s Warm Visit, a Cold Reality
item.description: Bucolic scenes cast President Xi Jinping as a paternal leader in the mold of Mao, at home with rustic virtues, but those images do not match reality.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: British Retailer’s Straight Croissants Leave Some Bent Out of Shape
item.description: The supermarket chain Tesco is dispensing with the traditional form and will sell only ones without curves, citing a “spreadability factor.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: An apprentice removing fresh croissants at the National Bakery and Pastry Institute in Rouen, France.

item.title: Nairobi Park’s Lions, a Draw for Tourists, Take a Trip of Their Own
item.description: A number of lions that slipped out of Nairobi National Park on Friday, but the police did not report any unwanted encounters.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Wardens with the Kenya Wildlife Service carried tranquilizer guns as they searched for lions who escaped Nairobi National Park on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere: Speak Uighur? Have Good Vision? China’s Security Services Want You
item.description: An advertisement on a career website at a Chinese university offers a glimpse into what skills the state security system finds valuable for employees.
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A view of Shanghai in January. The Shanghai State Security Bureau is recruiting university graduates with skills in computers and ethnic minority languages.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Fighting Truancy Among India’s Teachers, With a Pistol and a Stick
item.description: Manoj Mishra carries a pistol to defend himself as he fights a big obstacle to improving the largest primary school system in the world: absent teachers.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manoj Mishra, a district education officer, right, talked to a school principal in Deoria, India, this month.

item.title: Lung Cancer Deaths Soar in China’s Steel Country, Report Says
item.description: Researchers say the cause of the fourfold rise since the 1970s in Hebei Province, a steel-making center, is probably air pollution.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A steel factory in Hebei Province, which surrounds Beijing. Satellite photos of northern China regularly show a miasma of smog centered on the province.

item.title: Q. And A.: Dispute Over Kurds Threatens U.S.-Turkey Alliance
item.description: Here are five questions about the Kurds and their role in the rapidly evolving events in Syria and Turkey.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A Kurdish fighter in January 2015 in the wreckage of a building in the center of the Syrian town of Kobani on the Turkish border.

item.title: Letter From Africa: Truth, Reconciliation and Now, a Prosecution in South Africa
item.description: Four police officers will be tried in the torture and murder of an anti-apartheid courier in 1983, a triumph for the judicial process, however slow.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Search Uncovers Body of Last Missing Person
item.description: The discovery brings the death toll from the Feb. 6 earthquake to 117, all but two of whom perished in the collapse of a 17-story apartment complex.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Heavy machinery excavating the Wei-Guan Golden Dragon apartment complex in Tainan, Taiwan. The remains of a homeless woman, the last known victim of the Feb. 6 earthquake, were found on Thursday.

item.title: In Defense of Trump, Some Point (Wrongly) to Vatican Walls
item.description: Scholars say a basic misunderstanding of the geography and history of Vatican City is at the center of criticism that the pope is being hypocritical in his remarks about Donald Trump’s call to build a wall between the U.S. and Mexico.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City in 2013.

item.title: World Briefing: Ghana: Dozens Killed in Road Accident
item.description: A head-on collision between a passenger bus and a truck killed at least 61 people in the deadliest road accident in recent memory in the country, officials and witnesses said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Governing Coalition Splinters
item.description: The governing coalition lost its majority in Parliament after a second faction bailed out.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Going to Cuba; First Visit by U.S. President in 88 Years
item.description: The visit is part of an effort to end more than a half-century of estrangement and forge normalized relations with a Cold War adversary.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Raúl Castro of Cuba, left, with President Obama at the United Nations in New York in September.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Unicef Warns of Conflict’s Toll on Children
item.description: More than 500,000 children in eastern Ukraine have been “deeply affected” by the trauma of living through the violence between government forces and insurgents that began two years ago, Unicef said.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Red Cross Halts Work in Ghazni Province After Kidnappings
item.description: An armed group abducted five local staff members of the international aid organization on a road in the province, where there have been frequent kidnappings and murders on the highways.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Donald Trump Fires Back at Sharp Rebuke by Pope Francis
item.description: Mr. Trump’s attack on Francis reflected a political calculation that criticizing the pope will not hurt him with conservatives — and might even improve his standing in South Carolina.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK HEALY
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, signing an autograph in South Carolina on Thursday. Polls suggest that the state’s primary contest is tightening.
